title: U.K.’s Average Rents Hit a Record-High in August
text:
Average rents in the U.K. reached an all-time high of £970 (US$1,208) in August, according to a report Friday by HomeLet.



That’s a 2.4% rise over August 2018 rents, the rental index from the U.K.-based lettings insurance company found. More people are choosing to rent homes instead of buying as Brexit uncertainty continues, according to HomeLet’s CEO Martin Totty.



More: Rising Rents, Wary Buyers Means Now Might Be the Time to Buy an Investment Property

“In times of uncertainty people tend to defer major purchases—opting to wait for the turbulent times to pass,” he said in the report. “In the case of Brexit—deal or no-deal—it is still unclear how long the uncertainty will continue, which could spell positive news for private landlords as more people choose to rent rather than risk entering the property market at the wrong point in the cycle.”



HomeLet monitors 12 areas for its monthly index, and all of them showed a year over year rental increase in August. In London, average rents were up 3.5% to £1,689, 74.1% higher than the U.K. average.



When London is taken out of the equation, the average rent in the U.K. was £802 in August, a 2% bump over the same month in 2018, the report found. London’s were 110.6% higher than the rest of the country.



Westminster had the highest average rent of the London boroughs in August at £2,526 a month. Lambeth and Camden had the second and third highest average rental prices, £2,150 and £2,137, respectively.

With rents on the rise, landlords are taking advantage, according to the report.



“Thanks to strong demand for rental stock, continued wage growth and a near all-time high level of employment, landlords hold some pricing power and seemingly are now beginning to exercise it,” Mr. Totty noted in the report.
